Posts.Content: Dec 4, 2010 01:08AM grammajan627 wrote: First I'm throwing out good thoughts to Zogo, who was scheduled for her BMX today. I hope she gets back to us on how she is doing! Second, I too had prolyphic AL&DH and chose a BMX after years of mammograms/magnified views/ultrasounds/MRIs/excisional biopsies/aspirations/biopsies with wire localizations/stereotactic biopsies - you name it, I think I had it all. At the end (pre BMX) I was having mammograms every 6 months - called back for mag view & ultrasounds, stereotactic and/or excisions biopsies (once they tried for 2 hour <OUCH> using sterotactic which failed and I ended up with yet another excisional biopsy). Then it was time for the 6 month mammogram again. What a circus! The last stereotactic turned up prolyphic AL&D with probable LCIS. My surgeon and the radiolgist agreed that it was not "if," it was "when" and my insurance would cover a BMX. Enough said. That was Nov. 21, 2008. I am now going through TEs with implant hopefully in March. I can't tell you the burden that was lifted when I had the mastecomy! I really couldn't wait to have them gone.

Posts.Content: Dec 4, 2010 04:12PM - edited Aug 20, 2013 07:49PM by grammajan627 Mild hyperplasia = cells have increased but aren't atypical (abnormal) and only in the ducts. This is good. Not sure how old you are, but as you age this may progress to more hyperplastic cells and they may become atypical - hopefully not. You will just be "watched" - maybe have mamograms every year or every 6 months. Digital mammography, magnified views and ultrasound have certainly given the surgeons/radiologists more information than ever before. In comparison, my "benign" diagosis was prolyphic ductal and lobular atypical hyperplasia. When it became apparent that the cells were increasing the size/width of both the ducts and lobes, they suggested a bilateral mastecomy (age 58). The risk was very high for producing cancer cells that could travel. It wasn't "if" - it was "when." I'm glad they have this 'baseline' for you - make sure you have that path report if you ever change doctors. So happy for you! (Isn't it agonizing waiting for results?)  Here is more hyperplasia information. http://www.cancer.org/Healthy/FindCancerEarly/WomensHealth/Non-CancerousBreastConditions/non-cancerous-breast-conditions-hyperplasia
